text: I'm a sixth generation farmer I want this land and these resources to be available to my children and their children and future Generations so caranada has the potential to improve soil Health has immediate benefits and potentially long-term benefits as well it's a crop with a high level of biomass so if you consider like the nutrient content and that new crop that's not normally in the system being introduced back into the rotation whether it's cultivated and minimally or in a minimal or no-till situation that decomposition is going to just bring a level of nutrients back to the to the soil profile it's going to be available for the next crop and because of the layer of residue that it leaves behind you have improvements in water retention and nutrient retention for the next cash crop for the farmers so there's all of these benefits aside from having Financial benefits for the grower it's hard to get good nutrient and water retention in our sandy soil caranata has a great fit in our system it kind of breaks up the monotony of the same crop year after year or two crops in rotation year after year by adding some biodiversity into the soil putting in nutrients back to the soil that we didn't previously have introduced there but the biggest thing is if there is some economic benefit to the grower market prices don't really change when our commodity crops fertilizer costs fuel costs continue to go up and up and up and so if you add in a new crop into a farming system that's very low input and you get so many benefits from it in terms of the soil Health aspect but also an immediate benefit because it's a harvestable grain crop foreign
